prereq: 6 units of courses labelled Art at the 300 level.

title: Advanced Visual Research Methods
info: Students pursue individually designed arts-based research projects, examine approaches to editing, sequencing, and presenting projects to an audience. Projects normally will be completed using digital photography.
prereq: Art 361.

title: Sculpture: Materials and Processes
info: Technical and conceptual exploration of sculpture through materials and processes. This may include a range of methods such as mold-making, casting, assemblage, carving, welding, forging, riveting, time-based media, installation or digital media.
prereq: Art 233.

title: Sculpture: Concepts and Strategies
info: Conceptual and professional exploration of sculpture introducing students to strategies and concepts to assist in research and problem solving. Approaches may include understanding object-hood, material as content, serial art, art movements impacting sculpture, public art, and sculpture and the market.
prereq: Art 233.

title: Professional Development
info: Professional development activities, documentation and dissemination associated with working as a professional artist, including intellectual property, ethics, and the context of different art communities.
prereq: 12 units of courses labelled Art.

title: Advanced Topics in Indigenous Art
info: Advanced studio inquiry into Indigenous art developing students’ technical and conceptual skills. Explores advanced practices through topics that may include beading, quilling, and hide.
prereq: Art 314.

title: Advanced Topics in Digital Arts
info: Advanced studio inquiry into digital art forms developing students’ technical and conceptual skills. Advanced exploration of digital media topics such as 2D graphics, 3D graphics, animation, motion capture, and modelling will enable research creation directed toward self-generated practice.
prereq: 15 units of courses labelled Art at the 300 level including 3 units from Art 313, 331, 319, 323, 334.

title: 3D Digital Imaging
info: Creative research in 3D digital visualization and fabrication involving multimedia software and hardware. May include 3D printing, rapid prototyping, laser cutting, and computer controlled milling.
prereq: 15 units of courses labelled Art at the 300 level, including 3 units from Art 313, 319, 323, 331, 334, 336.

title: Advanced Topics in Photography
info: Advanced studio inquiry into photography developing students’ foundational, technical and conceptual skills. Deeper exploration of topics in photography such as long term projects, narrative, projection, printing and alternative processes will enable research creation directed toward self-generated practice. Activities will include workshops, studio practice and critique.
prereq: 15 units of courses labelled Art at the 300 level including Art 332 or 338.

title: Advanced Topics in Drawing
info: Advanced studio inquiry into drawing that develops foundational, technical and conceptual skills. Deeper exploration of topics in drawing such as mixed media, street art and socio-political issues will enable research and creation directed toward self-generated practice.
prereq: 15 units of courses labelled Art at the 300 level, including 3 units from Art 341, 343, 345, 347, 349.

title: Painting: Expanded Field
info: Students explore an expanded field of painting through installing and contextualizing their work. This may include pictorial, spatial, performative, and conceptual responses to site. Students may engage in collage/assemblage, shaped canvases, text/image, objects, paint, and unconventional materials.
prereq: Art 231 or 241.

title: Advanced Topics in Painting
info: Advanced studio inquiry into painting developing students’ foundational, technical and conceptual skills. Deeper exploration of painting will enable research creation directed toward self-generated practice. Activities will include workshops, studio practice and critique. Topics offered may include murals, gender and the body, figure and landscape, or materiality.
prereq: 15 units of courses labelled Art at the 300 level including 3 units from Art 351 or 353.

title: Topics in Studio Research and Critique
info: A studio-based topics course that provides students with an opportunity for developing their exploration of contemporary and emerging creative research practices, contextualized via critique. Examples of topics: visiting artist, studio research, figure painting, visual research. Topics offered may include installation, research creation, site specific art.
prereq: 15 units of courses labelled Art at the 300 level including Art History 333.

title: Advanced Topics in Printmaking
info: Advanced studio inquiry into printmaking developing students’ technical and conceptual skills. The course will explore advanced practices in areas such as lithography, screenprinting, intaglio and photomechanical print processes.
prereq: 15 units of courses labelled Art at the 300 level, including 3 units from Art 373, 377, 379.

title: Sculpture: Mold Making and Casting
info: An exploration of mold making and casting techniques in the realization of sculptural forms.
prereq: Art 233.

title: Advanced Topics in Sculpture
info: Advanced studio inquiry into sculpture that develops technical and conceptual skills. Activities will include studio practice and critique enabling research creation directed toward self-initiated practice. Topics may include sculptural exploration of installation, performance, and site specific art.
prereq: 15 units of courses labelled Art at the 300 level including 3 units from Art 381 or 383.

title: Art in Theory and Practice II
info: Examination and discussion of theoretical issues associated with current practice in art.
prereq: Art 399 and admission to the BFA or BFA Honours in Visual Studies.

title: Advanced Topics in Media Arts
info: Advanced studio inquiry into media art forms developing students’ technical and conceptual skills. Topics may include: sound and interactivity, immersive art, tele-arts and projection mapping that will enable research creation directed toward self-generated practice.
prereq: 15 units of courses labelled Art at the 300 level including 3 units from Art 323, 315, 317, 321.

title: Computer Game Design
info: The game design process will be explored, including a history of video games, genres, game mechanics, design documents, and a summary of the development process. The focus will be on design, rather than development, and the artistic and creative assets, rather than the software. Students will design a game and will create a playable prototype. The principles will be applicable to other sorts of games, and to media art in general.
prereq: Art 251.

title: Curriculum Building for Art
info: Developing curriculum and program structures for formal and community art education. Program design includes current theory and practice and a field research component.
prereq: 12 units of courses labelled Art at the 300 level or above.

title: Directed Study
info: Independent studio research under the supervision of a faculty member.
prereq: Consent of the Department.

title: Honours Thesis
info: Independent studio research and production supported by a research paper for BFA Honours Visual Studies students, culminating in a Thesis Exhibition.
prereq: Admission to the BFA Honours Visual Studies Program.

title: Honours Studio Research I
info: Directed studio research and production for honours students.
prereq: Admission to Honours in Visual Studies and consent of the Department.

title: Honours Studio Research II
info: Further directed studio research and production for honours students.
prereq: Admission to Honours in Visual Studies and Art 561.

title: Advanced Studio Research and Critique
info: Advanced studio course that develops self-generated approaches to creative research and critique. Encourages engagement with contemporary and emerging practices and leads to critical fluency, contextualized via critique. Situated in an interdisciplinary setting, students can expect to encounter a wide range of themes and approaches to support their practice.
prereq: Art 465.

title: Foundations of Marketing
info: An introductory marketing course designed for management students to introduce the principles and practices of marketing. Topics will cover basic marketing concepts, societal issues, and the decision-making process of marketers in developing marketing strategies and plans. The focus of the course will be on the implementation of specific product, pricing, distribution and communication strategies for specific market situations.
prereq: Admission to the Haskayne School of Business, and 30 units including Strategy and Global Management 217.

title: Retail Management
info: A strategic approach to the retail industry. Managing the retail operation, including site selection, store design, consumer behaviour in retail situations, buying, inventory management, and visual merchandising. The role of retailing in the global economy.
prereq: Admission to the Haskayne School of Business and Marketing 317.

title: Business-To-Business Marketing
info: Marketing management and theory applied to the purchase of products and services by organizations. Topics include industrial market dynamics, organizational buying behaviour, relationship development, technology, and the importance of innovation.
prereq: Admission to the Haskayne School of Business and Marketing 317.

title: Marketing Communications
info: Evaluations of the roles of various communication tools including advertising, sales promotion, personal selling and public relations.
prereq: Admission to the Haskayne School of Business and Marketing 317.

title: Sales Management
info: Strategic and managerial aspects of professional selling and sales force management. Topics include sales forecasting, recruitment, training, motivation, compensation and territory management, CRM, integration of technology, sales professionalism/ethics.
prereq: Admission to the Haskayne School of Business and Marketing 317.

title: Marketing Research
info: Understanding how to conduct and evaluate research for management decision making. Emphasis on research design, measurement concepts, sample design, field work, statistical concepts, data analysis and reporting research findings. Practical application by doing a field research study.
prereq: Admission to the Haskayne School of Business and Marketing 317.

title: International Marketing
info: A course on the environment and basic principles underlying the design and implementation of marketing strategies across national and cross-cultural boundaries. Topics will follow the decision process of international marketers in researching the environment, planning the entry strategy and designing their activities on product, distribution, promotion and pricing.
prereq: Admission to the Haskayne School of Business and Marketing 317.

title: Digital Marketing
info: Examination of specific digital strategies, tactics and platforms to understand the concepts of digital and interactive marketing. Topics include social media, user-generated content, mobile marketing and display advertising.
prereq: Admission to the Haskayne School of Business and Marketing 317.

title: Product Management
info: An in-depth examination of product management issues facing organizations. This includes strategic innovation, product portfolio, new product/service development, brand management, and diffusion of technology.
prereq: Admission to the Haskayne School of Business and Marketing 317.

title: Consumer Behaviour
info: Study of factors influencing consumer behaviour. Topics include consumer judgment and decision-making, persuasion, emotional, motivational, social, cultural and contextual influences on decision-making, as well as methods of gaining consumer insights.
prereq: Admission to the Haskayne School of Business and Marketing 317.

title: Services Marketing
info: Application of the managerial practices and theory related to services marketing. Topics include management and measurement of service quality, service recovery. The linking of customer measurement to performance measurement, and cross-function issues through integration of marketing with disciplines such as operations and human resources.
prereq: Admission to the Haskayne School of Business and Marketing 317.

title: Strategic Marketing
info: Marketing strategy is explored in the context of overall corporate strategy. Integrates the aspects of the market mix into formal planning systems. The focus of the course is on strategic responses to changing customer needs and competitive activities.
prereq: Admission to the Haskayne School of Business and 84 units including Marketing 317.

title: Financial Management
info: An introduction to the allocation of financial capital, from a theoretical as well as a practical perspective. The course builds on a modern understanding of how risk, time horizon, and market imperfections each affect the value of real and financial assets. Topics include time value of money, the risk-return trade-off, financial investing, corporate financing, and corporate investing.
prereq: Admission to the Haskayne School of Business, 30 units including Mathematics 249 or 265, Economics 201 and 203, Accounting 217, Management Studies 217, and either a) Statistics 213 and 217 or b) Mathematics 211 and one of Digital Engineering 319, Electrical Engineering 419 or Engineering 319.

title: Canadian Business Finance
info: An introduction to business financial management practices in Canada including investment decision, capital markets, and sources, uses and costs of capital over short, intermediate and long run situations.
prereq: 30 units.

title: Personal Financial Management
info: An introduction to personal financial management practices in Canada. Topics discussed may include goal setting, personal financial statements, the mathematics of personal finance, taxation, general and life insurance, retirement planning, investments, and estate planning. Completion of the course should enable students to properly prepare and plan their own financial future.
prereq: 30 units.

title: Security Analysis and Investments
info: A comprehensive exploration of security analysis and investments aimed at advancing understanding of financial markets, valuation techniques, and portfolio selection under various investment objectives. Topics such as capital allocation, diversification, security (stocks, bonds, derivatives) valuation, and market efficiency are covered.
prereq: Admission to the Haskayne School of Business and Finance 317.

title: Futures and Options
info: Extensive introduction to the operation of derivative markets and the valuation of derivative securities. Typical derivatives including forward and future contracts, options, and interest rate derivatives will be covered.
prereq: Admission to the Haskayne School of Business, Finance 317 and 443.

title: Capital Budgeting
info: Capital investment policies, real options, required rate of return calculation, tax factors, risk analysis, buy versus lease, abandonment considerations.
prereq: Admission to the Haskayne School of Business, Finance 317 and 451.

title: Trading and Market Data Management
info: Introduction to accessing data feeds as they are used by professional financial market traders and analysts. Data for stock, bond, futures and options markets, accounting statements and securities commission filings, as well as real-time and historical news events and analysis will be studied.
prereq: Admission to the Haskayne School of Business, Finance 317 and consent of the Haskayne School of Business.

title: Corporate Finance
info: A deeper understanding of topics such as capital budgeting, capital structure, valuation, payout policy, and financing decisions.
prereq: Admission to the Haskayne School of Business and Finance 317.

title: International Finance
info: A study of the forces affecting the financial environment of the corporate sector which appear to stem from requirements in the international sector. Balance-of-payments problems, exchange rates, currency risk hedging techniques, international reserve creations and transfers are some of the major elements studied.
prereq: Admission to the Haskayne School of Business, Finance 317 and 443.

title: Portfolio Theory and Management
info: Analysis of the major aspects of the grouping of financial assets. Portfolio analysis and its application to portfolio management, capital market theory and the measurement of financial performance in the presence of risk.
prereq: Admission to the Haskayne School of Business, Finance 317 and 443.

title: Mergers and Acquisitions
info: A study of the economic theory and practical issues around takeover and takeover defence strategies. Valuation issues, corporate restructuring, corporate governance, and methods of ensuring congruence between management and shareholder goals are also discussed.
prereq: Admission to the Haskayne School of Business, Finance 317 and 451.

title: Financial Risk Management
info: A framework for evaluating financial risks and managing them with the use of financial securities including derivatives. Includes firm valuation with risk management, value-at-risk, testing financial models, optimal hedging strategies, energy risk management, market risk, static versus dynamic strategies, interest rate risk, credit risk and liquidity risk. Case analysis of financial disasters due to risk management failures.
prereq: Admission to the Haskayne School of Business, Finance 317 and 443.

title: UCeed Haskayne Student Fund
info: A comprehensive hands-on course on the financing of early-stage companies. Students will be responsible for evaluating investment opportunities, performing due diligence, working as a team to select investment recommendations, writing investment recommendation reports to an Investment Advisory Group, and participating in quarterly Investment Review Meetings.
prereq: Admission to the Haskayne School of Business, Finance 317 and consent of the Haskayne School of Business.

title: The Calgary Portfolio Management Trust
info: Hands-on application of portfolio management theory. Students report to a board as fiduciary fund managers their evaluation of risk-return tradeoffs, security selection, financial reporting, and program management.
prereq: Admission to the Haskayne School of Business, Finance 317 and consent of the Haskayne School of Business.

title: New Venture Finance
info: Application of financial theory and analysis to the valuation and financing of new ventures. Course balances learning of concepts, development of analytical skills, and practice in decision making. Opportunity to apply learning to live projects.
prereq: Admission to the Haskayne School of Business and Finance 317.

title: Management of Financial Institutions
info: Management of funds and their allocation among cash, primary reserves, loans and investments to provide liquidity and earnings. Services to depositors. Consideration of factors involved in the lending decision, pricing of services, branch location, etc. Strategies for maintaining profitability and liquidity in the face of changing monetary policy.
prereq: Admission to the Haskayne School of Business, Finance 317 and 451.

title: Personal Financial Management in Canada
info: An introduction to personal financial management in Canada. Topics covered may include goal setting, personal financial statements analysis, the time value of money, the Canadian personal income tax system, taxation issues for small businesses, risk management, an introduction to investments, retirement planning and estate planning. Students will be expected to display a comprehensive knowledge of the tools necessary to complete their own personal financial plan.
prereq: Admission to the Haskayne School of Business and 48 units including Finance 317.

title: Corporate Risk Management
info: Introduction to the management of operational and hazard risks based on contemporary financial theories, including risk identification, loss estimation, risk control, risk financing with insurance and other techniques, and enterprise risk management.
prereq: Admission to the Haskayne School of Business and Finance 317.

title: FinTech
info: Links conventional finance theory to FinTech-new technological innovations and their applications in finance. Topics include blockchain, cryptocurrency, smart contracts, crowdfunding, ICOs, machine learning, and other current topics.
prereq: Admission to the Haskayne School of Business and Finance 317.

title: Financial Analysis and Valuation
info: Cross-disciplinary course merges the principles of corporate financial valuation and advanced financial statement analysis. Course delivery focuses on cases and practical, evidenced-based applications, and features interaction with industry experts.
prereq: Admission to the Haskayne School of Business and Finance 317.

title: Selected Topics in Financial Management
info: Investigation of selected topics related to financial management, emphasizing the application of financial management principles to actual problems in the corporate sector.
prereq: Admission to the Haskayne School of Business and Finance 317. For certain topics, consent of the Haskayne School of Business will also be required.

title: Introduction to Biochemistry
info: Emphasis is placed on analyzing the chemistry of biochemical molecules including proteins, carbohydrates, lipids, and nucleic acids. The chemistry of biomolecules is applied to prerequisite knowledge of cell structures and life processes. Basic concepts of metabolism are introduced, focusing on the breakdown of carbohydrates for energy. The laboratory component reinforces learning of the lecture material, while teaching technical skills and the analysis and interpretation of experiments involving biochemical molecules.
prereq: Chemistry 351, Biology 311 and admission to a Major offered by the Department of Biological Sciences or the Neuroscience Major or a primary concentration in Biological Sciences in either the Natural Sciences or Environmental Science Major. Or, Chemistry 351, and Medical Science 341, and admission to either the Biomedical Science or Bioinformatics Major.
antireq: Credit for Biochemistry 393 and 341 will not be allowed.

title: Honours Research Thesis
info: Each student will be assigned a project in consultation with a supervisor. Written reports and oral presentations are required.
prereq: Physics 443 and 449 and 455 and consent of the Department.

title: Senior Research Thesis
info: Each student will be assigned a project in consultation with a supervisor. Written reports and oral presentations are required.
prereq: Consent of the Department.
notes: A maximum of 6 units may be taken. MAY BE REPEATED FOR CREDIT

title: Statistics for the Physical and Environmental Sciences
info: Introduction to the collection of data. Probability and probability distributions. Single and Multi-sample estimation of distribution parameters. Regression and Goodness of Fit tests. Experimental Design and Analysis of Variance.
prereq: 3 units from Mathematics 249, 265 or 275.
antireq: Credit for Statistics 327 and any one of Statistics 205, 213 or 217 will not be allowed.

title: Introduction to Probability
info: A calculus-based introduction to probability theory and applications. Elements of probabilistic modelling, Basic probability computation techniques, Discrete and continuous random variables and distributions, Functions of random variables, Expectation and variance, Multivariate random variables, Conditional distributions, Covariance, Conditional expectation, Central Limit Theorem, Applications to real-world modelling.
prereq: Mathematics 267 or 277.
antireq: Credit for Statistics 321 and Engineering 319 will not be allowed.

title: Introduction to Theoretical Statistics
info: Statistics and their distributions. Introduction to statistical inference through point estimation and confidence interval estimation of a population parameter. Properties of statistics including unbiasedness and consistency in estimation. Single parameter hypothesis testing, Type I and Type II Error. Multi-parameter estimation through confidence interval estimation and hypothesis testing. The analysis of bivariate data through simple linear regression, including inferences on the parameters of the linear model and the analysis of variance. Chi-square test of independence and goodness of fit test.
prereq: Statistics 321.
antireq: Credit for Statistics 323 and Data Science 305 will not be allowed.
